Investigating fit of #PNT to an #IRT measurement model: See also its companion

citation.abstract:
In this study, we investigated fit of Philadelphia Naming Test (PNT) to an item response theory (IRT) measurement model, estimated the precision of the resulting scores and item parameter estimates, and provided a theoretical rationale for the interpretation of PNT overall scores by relating explanatory variables to item difficulty. This paper describes the statistical model underlying the computer adaptive PNT presented in a companion paper (Hula, Kellough, and Fergadiotis, under review).
Using archival data, we evaluated fit of the PNT to 1- and 2-parameter logistic (1-PL, 2-PL) models and examined the precision of the resulting parameter estimates. We regressed the item difficulty estimates on three predictor variables: word length, age of acquisition, and contextual diversity.
The 2-PL model demonstrated marginally better fit, but 1-PL model fit was adequate. Precision was excellent for both person ability and item difficulty estimates. Word length, age of acquisition, and contextual diversity all independently contributed to variance in item difficulty.
IRT methods can be productively used to analyze and quantify anomia severity in aphasia. Regression of item difficulty on lexical variables supported the validity of the PNT and interpretation of anomia severity scores in the context of current word finding models.
